title: How to Know if Fish Is Cooked

steps.headline: Serve the fish only after it reaches 140 °F (60 °C).
steps.description: Stick the pointy end of a meat thermometer into the thickest portion of the fillet. Try to position the thermometer so it’s halfway down the fish, and not touching the cooking surface. If the thermometer reads 135 °F (57 °C) or higher, stop cooking the fish. Even after you take the fillet off of the cooking surface, it will still continue to cook from residual heat. If the fillet or fish slice is over the designated internal temperature, there’s a chance that your fish might be overcooked.

steps.headline: Twist a fork into the fish’s surface to see if it flakes.
steps.description: Leave the fish on the cooking surface or appliance while checking it for doneness. Without burning yourself, take a fork and stick it halfway into the slice of fish. Turn the fork gently to see if the fish flakes apart under a small amount of pressure. If the fish doesn’t flake or separate slightly, then it needs to be cooked for longer. Underdone fish tends to be firm on the inside. While you don’t want to cook the fish for too long, you definitely want to avoid serving a fish that feels firm to the touch.

steps.headline: Slide a butter knife along the center of the fish to see if the meat is opaque.
steps.description: To preserve the smooth appearance of your fish slice or fillet, take a dinner knife and run it along the center crease/seam of the fish. Use the flat edge of the knife to peel back the outer layer of the meat, which allows you to see how done the fish is. If the fish still looks translucent, then be sure to cook it for longer. Cooked fish should look cloudy and opaque in color.

steps.headline: Cook any fish 7-10 minutes for every 1 inch (2.5 cm) of thickness.
steps.description: Split that time in half when you’re working with a very thin piece of fish, as these only take about 3-4 minutes. Whenever you’re preparing fish on a skillet or pan, flip the fish over at the midway point of the cooking process. For instance, if you’re pan-searing or sautéing a piece of fish that’s 1 inch (2.5 cm) thick, be sure to flip it over between 3½ and 5 minutes of cooking time.

steps.headline: Don’t flip the fillets while they’re baking.
steps.description: Take note of how long you’ve been cooking the fish for when you go to check on the baking fillets. If a quick inspection reveals that the fish pieces aren’t baked enough, let them cook for 2-4 more minutes. Since fish can go from underdone to overdone very quickly, be sure to bake in small increments of time. If a baked fish flakes after you press on the surface with the back of a spoon, then it’s ready to be served. This is an especially good way to test larger fish, like salmon, cod, sea bass, and halibut.

steps.headline: Pan-sear fillets until they’re golden on each side.
steps.description: Pay attention to the color of your fillets as you cook them. When pan-searing a fish, follow the thickness rule to ensure that you’re not overcooking or undercooking the meat. If your fish slices appear crispy and golden on the outside, then they’re ready to be served. Try not to pan-sear fish for too long. While you don’t want to undercook the fish, a fillet that’s brown or black won’t taste as delicious.

steps.headline: Keep your skillet hot whenever you sauté fish.
steps.description: Cook your fish slices evenly by heating up the skillet to a medium-high setting. If you want to keep a sharp eye on how long you’ve been cooking your fish, be sure to maintain a consistent, medium-high heat whenever you sauté an underdone fillet. Wait for the fish to look opaque on 1 side before flipping it over again. Remember: you can always cook an underdone fish, but you can’t undercook an overdone fish! When the back of the fish is able to flake lightly, remove it from the pan.

steps.headline: Grill fish until they can flake likely when prodded with a fork.
steps.description: Place your fillets over medium coal heat, or with the temperature of a gas appliance set to medium. Keep your fish centered over the coals so each piece can cook evenly. If you’re grilling several fillets, place them in a grill basket before setting them over the cooking surface. Once the fish begins to look opaque, flip it over to cook the opposite side. Grilled fish only need to be flipped once.

steps.headline: Broil the fish for an additional few minutes if it seems underdone.
steps.description: Since broiling occurs at extremely high temperatures, always recook your fish in small increments of time. After inspecting the fillets, slide the top rack back into the oven for another 2-5 minutes, depending on how long it’s already been in the oven. Don’t overdo the cooking time when you broil, as this could lower the flavor and texture quality of the fish! Once the fish looks golden and crispy on the outside, it’s ready to be served. Pull the rack out to inspect the fish—don’t remove the cooking tray completely until you’re sure that the fillets are cooked.
